channel.title: New "Earth like" planet
channel.description:
Scientists say that they have discovered a new planet in the constellation of libra 20 light years away. The planet is has a red dwarf sun and one year is only about two weaks(earth time). So really, by the time humans get to the planet the star will have burnt out making the planet unlivable because of the temperature of not having a sun.
Measurements of the planet's celestial path suggest it is 1½ times the size of our home planet, and orbits close to its sun, with a year of just 13 days. The planet's orbit brings it 14 times closer to its star than Earth is to the sun. But Gliese 581 burns at only 3,000C, half the temperature of our own sun, making conditions on the planet comfortable for life, with average ground temperatures estimated at 0 to 40C. Researchers claim the planet is likely to have an atmosphere.
Scientists have discovered a warm and rocky "second Earth" circling a star, a find they believe dramatically boosts the prospects that we are not alone. The planet is the most Earth-like ever spotted and is thought to have perfect conditions for water, an essential ingredient for life. Researchers detected the planet orbiting one of Earth's nearest stars, a cool red dwarf named Gliese 581.
"We wouldn't be surprised if there is life on this planet," said Stephane Udry, an astronomer on the project at the Geneva Observatory in Switzerland.

item.title: New "Earth like" planet
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Slave Scyth, post:29, topic:84841”]Screw that planet. Their probably just a bunch of Muslims anyways, right? If we met them it would just screw up us even more…

Why should we believe that their is life on that planet from the people who told us we are descendants of monkeys?[/quote]

No one said they are sure that there is life, they don’t even know much about this planet. As for the monkey comment, that is your opinion but don’t be an asshole about it. You know, our DNA is is something like 98.6% similar to a chimpanzee. And no one specifically said we came from that, we just evolved from a monkey form. There are plenty of bones(and skulls) backing up the theory.

Read full topic

item.title: New "Earth like" planet
item.dc:creator: @TestDummy TestDummy
item.description:
@TestDummy wrote:

Itachi Uchiha:

Correct me if I’m wrong but…don’t dwarf stars mean that it is in the stage before it turns into a supernova? So it should be about 5 times smaller than our sun.

A dwarf star is one that is in its main sequence, what happens to it towards the end of its ‘life’ is based on things such as mass.
Last I heard, our sun isn’t massive enough to supernova.

And looking it up, the mass and radius of this particular star is said to be a third of the sun.

Read full topic

[quote=“MybBob, post:18, topic:84841”][quote author=Itachi Uchiha link=topic=124520.msg1216729#msg1216729 date=1177548309]
Scientists say that they have discovered a new planet in the constellation of libra 20 light years away. The planet is has a red dwarf sun and one year is only about two weaks(earth time). So really, by the time humans get to the planet the star will have burnt out making the planet unlivable because of the temperature of not having a sun.

Measurements of the planet’s celestial path suggest it is 1½ times the size of our home planet, and orbits close to its sun, with a year of just 13 days. The planet’s orbit brings it 14 times closer to its star than Earth is to the sun. But Gliese 581 burns at only 3,000C, half the temperature of our own sun, making conditions on the planet comfortable for life, with average ground temperatures estimated at 0 to 40C. Researchers claim the planet is likely to have an atmosphere.

[quote]Scientists have discovered a warm and rocky “second Earth” circling a star, a find they believe dramatically boosts the prospects that we are not alone.
The planet is the most Earth-like ever spotted and is thought to have perfect conditions for water, an essential ingredient for life. Researchers detected the planet orbiting one of Earth’s nearest stars, a cool red dwarf named Gliese 581.[/quote]

“We wouldn’t be surprised if there is life on this planet,” said Stephane Udry, an astronomer on the project at the Geneva Observatory in Switzerland.

[/quote]

The sun is 5 times the size of our sun, but not as warm, but the planet is closer so it provides excellent living standards and it’s newer than our sun so it will burn out after ours.[/quote]Correct me if I’m wrong but…don’t dwarf stars mean that it is in the stage before it turns into a supernova? So it should be about 5 times smaller than our sun.

item.title: New "Earth like" planet
item.dc:creator: @MybBob MybBob
item.description:
@MybBob wrote:

[quote=“Itachi Uchiha, post:1, topic:84841”]Scientists say that they have discovered a new planet in the constellation of libra 20 light years away. The planet is has a red dwarf sun and one year is only about two weaks(earth time). So really, by the time humans get to the planet the star will have burnt out making the planet unlivable because of the temperature of not having a sun.

Measurements of the planet’s celestial path suggest it is 1½ times the size of our home planet, and orbits close to its sun, with a year of just 13 days. The planet’s orbit brings it 14 times closer to its star than Earth is to the sun. But Gliese 581 burns at only 3,000C, half the temperature of our own sun, making conditions on the planet comfortable for life, with average ground temperatures estimated at 0 to 40C. Researchers claim the planet is likely to have an atmosphere.

[quote]Scientists have discovered a warm and rocky “second Earth” circling a star, a find they believe dramatically boosts the prospects that we are not alone.
The planet is the most Earth-like ever spotted and is thought to have perfect conditions for water, an essential ingredient for life. Researchers detected the planet orbiting one of Earth’s nearest stars, a cool red dwarf named Gliese 581.[/quote]

“We wouldn’t be surprised if there is life on this planet,” said Stephane Udry, an astronomer on the project at the Geneva Observatory in Switzerland.[/quote]

The sun is 5 times the size of our sun, but not as warm, but the planet is closer so it provides excellent living standards and it’s newer than our sun so it will burn out after ours.

item.title: New "Earth like" planet
item.dc:creator: @TeraByte TeraByte
item.description:
@TeraByte wrote:

Well, apparently, traveling at the speed of light has been disproved…(I think it was Albert Einstein or some other genius). They proved that when you travel at the speed of light, your mass becomes infinite, so it would take an infinite amount of energy to move it or something. I think time also stops when you travel at the speed of light.
On the side note, I do believe other intelligent beings could exist on other planets. We have never discovered the limits of the universe, nor the limits of knowledge, so why should we limit our imagination?

Read full topic
